title: STM
text:
Research Directions


My research intersection of data management, AI/ML, and healthcare data science. I proposed serveral data quality improvement algorithms (missing data) for distributed healthcare networks. I also applied generative and preditive AI for statistical modeling for EHR and genomic data. Additionally, I develop privacy-enhancing technologies for healthcare, bioinformatics, and financial applications.



Research Projects & Publications


Stream1: Missing Data Imputation in Distributed Healthcare Networks

Our mission is to address the challenge of missing data imputation in distributed clinical networks. We develop imputation algorithms that enable healthcare institutions to collaboratively handle missing data without directly sharing sensitive patient information. These approaches allow improving data quality in distributed clinical networks for downstream analyses and AI models. We developed a toolkit for distributed missing data imputation called FedImpute.



Min, S., et al. Cafe: Improved Federated Data Imputation by Leveraging Missing Data Heterogeneity. IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering
Min, S., et al. Exploring the inequitable impact of data missingness on fairness in machine learning, IEEE Intelligent Systems
Min, S., et al. FedImpute: A Framework for Distributed Missing Data Imputation Research with Python, Under Review Journal of Statistical Software
Min, S., et al. Impact of Missing Data on the Fairness of Decision Support Systems, Under Review Decision Support Systems





Stream2: Generative AI for Bioinformatics and EHR data

We also design solutions to apply generative AI for data generation in genomic data for GWAS studies. We also collaborate with anesthesiologists, developing statistical models to support their clinical research. Currently, I’m also interested in real-world evidence analyses on publicly available datasets, e.g., MIMIC. We are developing tools to collect, process, analyze and benchmark public medical datasets called MedDataKit and we are benchmarking ML/DL based clinical prediction models combined with multimodal information for perioperative surgical data for postoperative complications prediction.



Wang, X., Min, S., & Vaidya, J. Exploring Synthetic Genomes for Genome-wide Association Studies. Under Review Bioinformatics
Wang, X., Min, S., & Vaidya, J. Exploring the use of Artificial Genomes for Genome-wide Association Studies through the lens of Utility and Privacy, AMIA Annual Symposium 2024
Wang, X., Min, S., & Vaidya, J. Descriptor: Synthetic Genomic Dataset with Diverse Ancestry (SynGen6). IEEE Data Descriptions
Gao, X., Min, S., et al. Comparing Ventilation Modes for Elderly Patients in Prone Spinal Surgery: A Randomized Trial, Under Review BMC Journal of Anesthesiology
Yin, W., Min, S., et al. Intrapulmonary Shunt and Oxygenation During One-Lung Ventilation: Influence of Dexmedetomidine Combined with TAES, Under Review Journal of Clinical Anesthesia
Li, J., Min, S., et al. Impact of Dexmedetomidine and Static Lung Inflation on Post-Cardiopulmonary Bypass Pulmonary Function in Valve Surgery Patients, Under Review BMC Journal of Anesthesiology





Stream3: Secure AI for Finance Risk Management

We propose a federated XGBoost model for financial crime prediction as the 1st prize solution in US PETs Challenge. We also design solutions for data generation of SNPs data for GWAS studies for privacy preservation.



Asif, H., Min, S., Wang, X., & Vaidya, J. US-UK PETs prize challenge: Anomaly detection via privacy-enhanced federated learning. IEEE transactions on privacy. (Best Paper Award 2024)





Other Research

Previously, I had experience analyzing software commit history and wifi-connection data.



Min, S., et al. CrowdMap: Spatiotemporal Visualization of Anonymous Occupancy Data for Pandemic Response. ACM SIGSPATIAL 2021
He, J., Min, S., et al. The characteristics and impact of uncompilable code changes on software quality evolution. IEEE International Conference on Software Quality, Reliability and Security (QRS) 2020

title: STM
text: My research focuses on healthcare data analysis & data privacy, primarily addressing missing data imputation in distributed networks. I also apply statistical modeling for clinical research and clinical prediction models using EHR data. Additionally, I develop privacy-enhancing technologies for healthcare, bioinformatics, and financial applications.

title: STM
section: Missing Data Imputation in Distributed Healthcare Networks
text:
Missing Data Imputation in Distributed Healthcare Networks
Our mission is to address the challenge of missing data imputation in distributed clinical networks. We develop imputation algorithms that enable healthcare institutions to collaboratively handle missing data without directly sharing sensitive patient information. These approaches allow improving data quality in distributed clinical networks for downstream statistical analyses and predictive tasks.



Min, S., et al. Cafe: Improved Federated Data Imputation by Leveraging Missing Data Heterogeneity. IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering. [Link]
Min, S., et al. FedImpute: A Framework for Distributed Missing Data Imputation Research with Python, submitted to Journal of Statistical Software, [Link]
Min, S., et al. Exploring the inequitable impact of data missingness on fairness in machine learning, IEEE Intelligent Systems [Link]
Min, S., et al. Stochastic Gradient Based MICE Imputation over Vertically Partitioned Data, work in progress
Min, S., et al. MICE imputation for Multi-center Study via External Knowledge Transfer, work in progress

title: STM
section: Statistical Analysis for Clinical Research & Evidence-Based Studies
text:
Statistical Analysis for Clinical Research & Evidence-Based Studies
I also collaborate with several anesthesiologists, developing statistical models and analyses to support their clinical research on topics such as patients’ respiratory function during surgery. Currently, I’m also interested in real-world evidence analyses on publicly available datasets, e.g., MIMIC.



Gao, X., Min, S., et al. Comparing Ventilation Modes for Elderly Patients in Prone Spinal Surgery: A Randomized Trial, submitted to BMC Journal of Anesthesiology [Draft]
Yin, W., Min, S., et al. Intrapulmonary Shunt and Oxygenation During One-Lung Ventilation: Influence of Dexmedetomidine Combined with TAES, submitted to Journal of Clinical Anesthesia [Draft]
Li, J., Min, S., et al. Impact of Dexmedetomidine and Static Lung Inflation on Post-Cardiopulmonary Bypass Pulmonary Function in Valve Surgery Patients, submitted to BMC Journal of Anesthesiology [Draft]

title: STM
text:
Work Experience




RU





Research Assistant | Sep 2023 - Present


Rutgers Institute for Data Science, Learning and Application




Data Quality Management and Artificial Intelligence
Designed missing data imputation algorithms for distributed healthcare networks and applied generative AI models (VAEs, GANs, transformers) for data quality improvement, focusing on utility, privacy, and ethical considerations to establish responsible AI practices in production environments.
Generative AI for Biomedical Informatics
Developed scalable GWAS algorithms in distributed environments and applied generative AI models (VAEs, GANs, Diffusion models) for Type 2 diabetes and dementia SNP analysis, advancing for early disease detection and personalized therapeutic target identification.
Financial Crime Detection using Secure Learning
Proposed XgBoost-based federated learning framework for detecting financial anomaly transactions, ensuring privacy and security of participant dataset.











Data Science Intern | June - Sep 2021


DvSum.ai




Data Management and Governance Layer for Enterprise AI
Developed an automated pipeline for data type (primitive, semantic) detection, advanced profiling, rule-based metadata matching and quality validation, and autonomous lineage tracking.
Automated Data Science Workflow
Created an end-to-end pipeline for autonomous data cleaning, profiling, feature transformation, and code generation to streamline data science team workflows.

title: STM
text:
Competitions and Awards


Kaggle CIBMTR - Equity in post-HCT Survival Predictions, Silver Medal (74/3084), 2025

Proposed ensembles of deep survivor models and XGBoost-based Cox survival using pseudo label techniques for survival risk prediction for hematopoietic cell transplant patients.

US PETs (Privacy-enhancing Technology) Challenge, Financial Crime Prevention, 1st Place (1/60)

Designed privacy-preserving federated XGBoost using Bloomfilter for financial crime detection.
Challenge Report: US-UK PETs Challenge | Solution: Scarlet-PETs

Kaggle Predict New Medicines with BELKA, Bronze Medal (178/1950), 2024

Processed protein data for molecule representation extraction using Pandas and BELKA and developed 1D CNN model in PyTorch for protein-molecule interaction prediction.

title: Sitao Min
text:
Sitao Min
    
      
        
      
      
        
      
      
        
      
      
        
      
      
        
      
    
  
  



Welcome to my personal website!

I am a Ph.D. candidate of Information System at Rutgers Business School under the supervision of Dr. Jaideep Vaidya. Before joining Rutgers, I obtained a M.S in Computer Science at University of Southern California and B.S. in Physics at Zhejiang University in China.
My expertise lies in the intersection of data management, AI/ML, and healthcare data science. I specialize in AI/ML applications for data quality improvement (e.g., missing data) and clinical, EHR, and genomics data analysis, as well as advancing generative AI techniques for synthetic healthcare data generation to address data privacy and ethical issues.

title: STM
text:
I am the author of the following packages and software projects:

FedImpute - Toolkit for Distributed Missing Data Imputation Research
